Articles.Content:
I've got an asteroid in a rather awkward orbit.

...specifically, an impact orbit.  It's coming in from an orbit outside Kerbin coming in and seems really hard to get to.  Every time I think I've found a good intercept, refining it ends up becoming "wait for it to hit".

How can I get there usefully early?

How close can a class C get before it's too late to divert it?

My plan starts when the asteroid enters Kerbin SoI. Doesn't matter if it's going to impact or a low flyby - you have enough time to do it without resorting to interplanetary. Usuaully stock asteroid spawn is at a solar orbit similar to Kerbin's, which means the velocity of asteroid is rather small when it enters Kerbin SoI. Therefore, it usually takes ~10 days before it reaches LKO, and 10 days is plenty of time.

First launch into its inclination. Then burn so that your apoapsis is at the place where the asteroid will roughly be - this involves some experience and trial and error, or if you wish, a manual computation of the desired intercept location - stock intercept computation can't deal with it ever since. When you get close enough to the asteroid, that's just routine rendezvous.

And also because the rendezvous point is still really far away (almost surely beyond Mun altitude), it takes minimal delta V just to divert it away from impacting course. Anything else with the asteroid (moving to another orbit, drilling, science, etc.) can come afterwards and orthogonal to things above.

Or you could intercept it while it's still well outside Kerbin's SoI.  The earlier before you get to Kerbin, the less dV you need to nudge it to make it miss.

(Of course, you're still going to need a lot of fuel to capture it.)

15 hours ago, Corona688 said:

How can I get there usefully early?

How close can a class C get before it's too late to divert it?

Well, as @FancyMouse and @Snark said, you have 2 choices:  inside or outside of Kerbin's SOI.  Both end up costing about the same amount of dV, they just distribute it in different phases of the flight.  This has implications for the design of the ship.  If you go for a Kerbin SOI, you need a bigger capture vehicle with more dV and TWR.  If you go for a solar intercept, the actual capture ship can be small and weak, but it needs a bigger transfer stage to get out there and then match velocities.

Achieving an intercept in solar orbit is rather difficult compared to within Kerbin's SOI.  I find that I usually have to make 3 or 4 burns some days/weeks apart to gradually reduce the closest approach distance down to nothing.  Then a relatively big burn to match velocities.  But out in solar orbit, you have lots of time so this isn't a big deal, and you have a big transfer stage to do this will.  Within Kerbin's SOI, you have less time so what generally happens is, you have to make 1 major burn to intercept and then another major burn to match velocities.  Then you still need enough left to divert the asteroid off impact and then, optionally, capture it into at least an elliptical orbit (which you can adjust later with another ship if desired).  This is why the capture ship is typically more macho for Kerbin's SOI.

OK.  Well, since I have time, I'm gonna try both   My little craft is enroute already, and should have plenty of dv to spare -- though that's when driving its OWN mass, not a 10m asteroid.  We will see.
